title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text: A list of common tidyverse/data.table commands that do (roughly) the same thing so that you can compare the syntax. Some opinions included.

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidyverse

Pros

easy to read
easy to write
approachable to beginners
many useful convenience functions
tibble pretty print



Cons

relatively slow (though improving over time)
can be verbose
big dependency footprint
more prone to interface changes
typical usage with nonstandard evaluation doesn‚Äôt play nicely with CRAN

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
data.table

Pros

insane performance üî•
concise
no dependencies other than R itself
some built in parallelization (but not on Mac without some pain)
some low-level features tidyverse probably won‚Äôt ever have (eg keys)



Cons

looks like a mish-mash of punctuation 6 months after the fact (this is gradually improving)
documentation can be arcane
modify by reference defies the general R convention of copy on modify
list columns don‚Äôt print as nicely

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidy

mt_tbl |> mutate(disp_per_cyl = disp / cyl)

# A tibble: 32 √ó 13
   model         mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear  carb
   <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Mazda RX4    21       6  160    110  3.9   2.62  16.5     0     1     4     4
 2 Mazda RX4 ‚Ä¶  21       6  160    110  3.9   2.88  17.0     0     1     4     4

 5 Hornet Spo‚Ä¶  18.7     8  360    175  3.15  3.44  17.0     0     0     3     2
 6 Valiant      18.1     6  225    105  2.76  3.46  20.2     1     0     3     1
 7 Duster 360   14.3     8  360    245  3.21  3.57  15.8     0     0     3     4
 8 Merc 240D    24.4     4  147.    62  3.69  3.19  20       1     0     4     2
 9 Merc 230     22.8     4  141.    95  3.92  3.15  22.9     1     0     4     2
10 Merc 280     19.2     6  168.   123  3.92  3.44  18.3     1     0     4     4

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
data.table

mt_dt[, disp_per_cyl := disp/cyl]

By default assignment by reference operations don‚Äôt print anything. You can tack an empty [] onto the end of that operation to get it to print.
OR, using the new DT()/let() syntax (requires development version of data.table):

mt_dt |> DT(, let(disp_per_cyl = disp/cyl)) |> head()

               model   mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am
              <char> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num>
1:         Mazda RX4  21.0     6   160   110  3.90 2.620 16.46     0     1
2:     Mazda RX4 Wag  21.0     6   160   110  3.90 2.875 17.02     0     1
3:        Datsun 710  22.8     4   108    93  3.85 2.320 18.61     1     1
4:    Hornet 4 Drive  21.4     6   258   110  3.08 3.215 19.44     1     0
5: Hornet Sportabout  18.7     8   360   175  3.15 3.440 17.02     0     0
6:           Valiant  18.1     6   225   105  2.76 3.460 20.22     1     0
    gear  carb disp_per_cyl
   <num> <num>        <num>
1:     4     4     26.66667
2:     4     4     26.66667
3:     4     1     27.00000
4:     3     1     43.00000
5:     3     2     45.00000
6:     3     1     37.50000


The data.table walrus operator / let() assign by reference, so the disp_per_cyl column is added to mt_dt without using <-. Let‚Äôs delete it.

mt_dt[, disp_per_cyl := NULL]

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
Multiple columns

mt_tbl |> mutate(disp_per_cyl = disp / cyl,
                 hp_per_disp  = hp / disp)

# A tibble: 32 √ó 14
   model         mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear  carb
   <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Mazda RX4    21       6  160    110  3.9   2.62  16.5     0     1     4     4
 2 Mazda RX4 ‚Ä¶  21       6  160    110  3.9   2.88  17.0     0     1     4     4
 3 Datsun 710   22.8     4  108     93  3.85  2.32  18.6     1     1     4     1
 4 Hornet 4 D‚Ä¶  21.4     6  258    110  3.08  3.22  19.4     1     0     3     1
 5 Hornet Spo‚Ä¶  18.7     8  360    175  3.15  3.44  17.0     0     0     3     2
 6 Valiant      18.1     6  225    105  2.76  3.46  20.2     1     0     3     1
 7 Duster 360   14.3     8  360    245  3.21  3.57  15.8     0     0     3     4
 8 Merc 240D    24.4     4  147.    62  3.69  3.19  20       1     0     4     2
 9 Merc 230     22.8     4  141.    95  3.92  3.15  22.9     1     0     4     2
10 Merc 280     19.2     6  168.   123  3.92  3.44  18.3     1     0     4     4
# ‚Ñπ 22 more rows
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: disp_per_cyl <dbl>, hp_per_disp <dbl>


versus

mt_dt[, `:=`(disp_per_cyl = disp / cyl,
             hp_per_disp  = hp / disp)]

# OR

mt_dt |>
  DT(, let(disp_per_cyl = disp / cyl,
           hp_per_disp  = hp / disp)) |>
  head()

               model   mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am
              <char> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num>

4:    Hornet 4 Drive  21.4     6   258   110  3.08 3.215 19.44     1     0
5: Hornet Sportabout  18.7     8   360   175  3.15 3.440 17.02     0     0
6:           Valiant  18.1     6   225   105  2.76 3.460 20.22     1     0
    gear  carb disp_per_cyl hp_per_disp
   <num> <num>        <num>       <num>
1:     4     4     26.66667   0.6875000
2:     4     4     26.66667   0.6875000
3:     4     1     27.00000   0.8611111
4:     3     1     43.00000   0.4263566
5:     3     2     45.00000   0.4861111
6:     3     1     37.50000   0.4666667


Cleanup:

mt_dt[,let(disp_per_cyl = NULL,
           hp_per_disp  = NULL)]

2 Lincoln Con‚Ä¶  10.4     8   460   215  3     5.42  17.8     0     0     3     4

data.table

mt_dt[disp > 450]

                 model   mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am
                <char> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num>

2: Lincoln Continental  10.4     8   460   215  3.00 5.424 17.82     0     0
    gear  carb

If the condition is a pre-existing column, enclose it in parentheses:

mt_dt[, big := disp > 450]

mt_dt[(big)]

                 model   mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am
                <char> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num> <num>
1:  Cadillac Fleetwood  10.4     8   472   205  2.93 5.250 17.98     0     0
2: Lincoln Continental  10.4     8   460   215  3.00 5.424 17.82     0     0
    gear  carb    big
   <num> <num> <lgcl>
1:     3     4   TRUE
2:     3     4   TRUE

mt_dt[, big := NULL]

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidy
They recently introduced .by arguments in dplyr 1.1.0, which to me is much cleaner than a separate call to group_by()

mt_tbl |> 
  summarise(avg_mpg = mean(mpg), .by = cyl)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
    cyl avg_mpg
  <dbl>   <dbl>
1     6    19.7
2     4    26.7
3     8    15.1

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
data.table
We use the data.table .() alias for list()

mt_dt[, .(avg_mpg = mean(mpg)), by = cyl]

     cyl  avg_mpg
   <num>    <num>
1:     6 19.74286
2:     4 26.66364
3:     8 15.10000

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidy
across() + where()

mt_tbl |> 
  transmute(across(where(is.character), 
                   ~str_sub(.x, 1, 5)))

# A tibble: 32 √ó 1
   model  
   <chr>  
 1 "Mazda"
 2 "Mazda"
 3 "Datsu"
 4 "Horne"
 5 "Horne"
 6 "Valia"
 7 "Duste"
 8 "Merc "
 9 "Merc "
10 "Merc "
# ‚Ñπ 22 more rows

mt_tbl |> 
  summarise(across(where(is.numeric),
                   sum))

# A tibble: 1 √ó 11
    mpg   cyl  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear  carb
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1  643.   198 7383.  4694  115.  103.  571.    14    13   118    90


^ You can replace the where() calls with everything() or matches('d') or c(mpg, cyl, disp), or any of the usual tidyselect patterns to pick out the columns needed.

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidy

df |> 
  separate_wider_delim(x, delim = '-',
                       names = c('x1', 'x2'))

# A tibble: 4 √ó 2
  x1    x2   
  <chr> <chr>
1 <NA>  <NA> 
2 x     y    
3 x     z    
4 y     z    


This is one circumstance where an interface change bit me. It used to be that separate() with a data.table input would return a data.table output, now it gets converted to a tibble. separate_wider_delim() is still listed as ‚Äúlifecycle: experimental‚Äù, so that may change too.

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
data.table

as.data.table(df)[, (c("x1", "x2")) := tstrsplit(x, split = "-")][]

        x     x1     x2
   <char> <char> <char>
1:   <NA>   <NA>   <NA>
2:    x-y      x      y
3:    x-z      x      z
4:    y-z      y      z


The tstrsplit() approach is ~10x faster than tidyr::separate(), but about the same as separate_wider_delim().

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidy

df |> unite(x,
            x1, x2,
            sep = "-")

    x
1 a-A
2 b-B
3 c-C
4 d-D
5 e-E

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
data.table

as.data.table(df)[, x := paste(x1, x2, sep = "-")][]

       x1     x2      x
   <char> <char> <char>
1:      a      A    a-A
2:      b      B    b-B
3:      c      C    c-C
4:      d      D    d-D
5:      e      E    e-E

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
tidy
Try input_tbl |> as.matrix() |> t() |> as_tibble() if your variable types work, otherwise try input_tbl |> pivot_longer() |> pivot_wider() as needed.

mt_tbl[1:4,] |> 
  column_to_rownames('model') |>
  as.matrix() |>
  t() |> 
  as.data.frame() |>
  rownames_to_column('variable') |> as_tibble()

# A tibble: 11 √ó 5
   variable `Mazda RX4` `Mazda RX4 Wag` `Datsun 710` `Hornet 4 Drive`
   <chr>          <dbl>           <dbl>        <dbl>            <dbl>
 1 mpg            21              21           22.8             21.4 
 2 cyl             6               6            4                6   
 3 disp          160             160          108              258

 7 qsec           16.5            17.0         18.6             19.4 
 8 vs              0               0            1                1   
 9 am              1               1            1                0   
10 gear            4               4            4                3   
11 carb            4               4            1                1

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations
text:
data.table

data.table::transpose(mt_dt[1:4,],
                      make.names = 'model', # MAKE this variable the new names
                      keep.names = 'variable') # KEEP the old names in this variable

    variable Mazda RX4 Mazda RX4 Wag Datsun 710 Hornet 4 Drive

title: Tidyverse/data.table translations

data.table

nested = mt_dt[, .(data = list(.SD)), by = cyl]
nested[, rbindlist(data), by = cyl] |> head()

     cyl          model   mpg  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear

4:     6        Valiant  18.1 225.0   105  2.76 3.460 20.22     1     0     3

    carb
   <num>
1:     4
2:     4
3:     1
4:     1
5:     4

If there‚Äôs only one column in the nested column:

dt[,unlist(data), by = group]

This can be adapted to unlisting multiple nested columns, but as far as I can tell it can‚Äôt unlist from one nested column into multiple nested columns.

title: andrewghazi.github.io
text:
Tidyverse/data.table translations












Sep 28, 2023


Andrew Ghazi






  




Integrated LOO walkthrough












Sep 22, 2023


Andrew Ghazi






No matching items

title: About
text: I‚Äôm a Statistical Geneticist at the Center for Computational Biomedicine at Harvard Medical School.

title: Integrated LOO walkthrough
text:
This is a guide/walkthrough on how to use the ‚ÄúIntegrated Importance Sampling‚Äù aka ‚ÄúIntegrated LOO‚Äù technique from (Vehtari et al., n.d.). I‚Äôve found myself needing to do this a couple times now, so I‚Äôm writing this walkthrough to:

crystallize my thoughts
record my notes on how it works / how it‚Äôs done
explain how it works in more depth than the existing example I know of
Demonstrate a more complicated example involving conditional parameter distributions
show how to perform the integral more flexibly in R / outside of Stan

Load some setup libraries:


Code
library(cmdstanr)

title: Integrated LOO walkthrough
section: Integrand at one point for one observation in one draw
text:
Integrand at one point for one observation in one draw
Let‚Äôs evaluate the integrand for an (arbitrarily selected) phylogenetic effect of 0.333 for the fifth observation on the first draw:


Code
vec_integrand(0.333,
    mu_bar_i1[5],
    sigma_bar_ij = sigma_bar_i1[5],
    draw_list[[1]]$sigma_resid, data_list$Y[5]
)


      t136 
0.02345266 


A reasonable-looking number, hooray!

title: Integrated LOO walkthrough
section: Integral for one observation in one draw
text:
Integral for one observation in one draw
Instead of just evaluating at an arbitrary point, let‚Äôs integrate it numerically. vec_integrand() as written actually has an analytic integral (the sum of two parabolas is just another parabola, so you can work out an expression for the integral), but I‚Äôm going to do it numerically for the more generic case (which I also do in anpan for logistic PGLMM LOO).
In the roaches example they use Stan‚Äôs built-in integrate_1d() function. While it‚Äôs nice to keep the log-likelihood calculation in the Stan program, the interface is unwieldy to me. You have to pass in ALL of the secondary real-valued arguments into the integrand function in a single argument, which is tricky when that includes many irregularly structured components. Same goes for integers. To me, doing the integral after the fact in R is much simpler. You can then hand the log-likelihood matrix directly to loo::loo().
The R function stats::integrate() uses adaptive quadrature to numerically integrate functions. I don‚Äôt know much about how it works, but it internally calls C code for the heavy lifting, so it‚Äôs pretty fast. It would be interesting to benchmark it against Stan‚Äôs integrate_1d().
Anyway, you just hand stats::integrate() the function, the integration range, and other needed arguments.


Code
integrate(vec_integrand,
    -Inf, Inf,
    mu_bar_ij = mu_bar_i1[5],
    sigma_bar_ij = sigma_bar_i1[5],
    sigma_resid = draw_list[[1]]$sigma_resid,
    yi = data_list$Y[5]
)


0.1941623 with absolute error < 3.8e-05


Another reasonable number, hooray!

title: Integrated LOO walkthrough
section: Integral for all observations in one draw
text:
Integral for all observations in one draw
Going further, let‚Äôs write a couple functions to evaluate the integral for all observations in a given draw:


Code
integrate_one_obs <- function(mu_bar_ij, sigma_bar_ij, Y,
    sigma_resid) {
    integrate(
        vec_integrand,
        -Inf, Inf,
        mu_bar_ij, sigma_bar_ij,
        sigma_resid, Y
    )$value
}

integrate_all_obs <- function(draw_j) {
    mu_bar_ij <- draw_j$phylo_effect_vectors[[1]] |> get_mu_bar_ij()
    sigma_bar_ij <- draw_j$sigma_phylo |> get_sigma_bar_ij(
        corr_minus_i_list,
        corr_12_list
    )

    mapply(integrate_one_obs,
        mu_bar_ij, sigma_bar_ij, data_list$Y,
        sigma_resid = draw_j$sigma_resid
    )
}


system.time({
    draw42_integrals <- integrate_all_obs(draw_list[[42]])
})

Fast, reasonable likelihoods!

title: Integrated LOO walkthrough
section: Integral for all observations, for one draw
text:
Integral for all observations, for one draw
Finally, let‚Äôs apply it to every posterior draw. I just remembered that purrr::map() recently introduced a .progress argument, let‚Äôs use it. purrr is sick.


Code
lik_mat <- purrr::map(draw_list,
    integrate_all_obs,
    .progress = interactive()
) |>
    purrr::reduce(rbind)


It only takes a minute on my laptop, but of course with larger datasets / more complicated models it can slow down a bit. That purrr::map() call is embarassingly parallelizable.
Finally we can see the loo results with the stable Pareto k diagnostics. We feed in the chain ID numbers so that loo is aware of the relative effective sample sizes:


Code
loo::loo(log(lik_mat),
    r_eff = loo::relative_eff(lik_mat,
        chain_id = draw_df$`.chain`
    )
)


Warning: Some Pareto k diagnostic values are slightly high. See help('pareto-k-diagnostic') for details.



Computed from 4000 by 150 log-likelihood matrix

         Estimate   SE
elpd_loo   -259.6  7.8
p_loo        16.5  1.7
looic       519.1 15.6
------
Monte Carlo SE of elpd_loo is 0.1.

Pareto k diagnostic values:
                         Count Pct.    Min. n_eff
(-Inf, 0.5]   (good)     149   99.3%   852       
 (0.5, 0.7]   (ok)         1    0.7%   1762      
   (0.7, 1]   (bad)        0    0.0%   <NA>      
   (1, Inf)   (very bad)   0    0.0%   <NA>      

All Pareto k estimates are ok (k < 0.7).
See help('pareto-k-diagnostic') for details.


Okay, so there may be one or two that are just ‚Äúok‚Äù, but way, way better and totally usable!
